video.title: Dead Rising Deluxe Remaster | Fully Ramblomatic

captions.text:
With the triple-A industry continuing to be 
analogous to an elderly, syphilitic dairy cow

that had to be harnessed to the ceiling after its 
last functioning leg fell off, the rest of the

year&#39;s looking pretty bleak for milk enthusiasts. 
But it&#39;s fucking A-1 prime cut season if you&#39;re

into remakes and remasters. We&#39;ve got Silent 
Hill 2 coming up, Lollipop Chainsaw remaster,

Epic Mickey remaster; I&#39;m sure that&#39;ll appease 
the fans who were clamoring for that, possibly

even both of them. And of course the Dead Rising 
Deluxe Remaster, or Druh Druh. And it occurred

to me that, while I&#39;ve reviewed Dead Rising 2, 
3 and 4, I never did the original because it

predated Zero Punctuation. Surreal to think of 
anything predating Zero Punctuation besides the

fuckin&#39; Cretaceous period. You wanna know how 
old Dead Rising 1 is? When it first came out,

people complained they couldn&#39;t read the 
tiny-winy HD text on their CRT televisions.

THAT&#39;S how old. Also, they couldn&#39;t hear the 
audio very well because the fucking Spanish

Civil War was going on outside their window. 
I&#39;m very fond of the Dead Rising series,

and the original is one of the best. Despite its 
age, there still isn&#39;t anything much like it,

and I like the way almost all its idiosyncrasies 
sprang fully formed right out of the gate.

You play as Frank West, daring photojournalist 
who&#39;s covered wars, y&#39;know, and who looks—and

I say this with affection—like every single part 
of his face got stung by bees at the same time.

Frank helicopters himself into the heart of 
a zombie-infested midwestern town and ends up

stranded at the weirdly massive shopping mall. 
He&#39;s got 72 hours before his ride comes back

to pick him up, and whether you spend that time 
following the critical path of story missions to

uncover the truth behind the catastrophe or 
piss about in a gingham dress, ramming your

tricycle into the shins of the undead is entirely 
up to you. I suppose you could call it a sandbox,

but only if the sandbox in this metaphor has had 
all the sand replaced with used heroin needles

and angry drunken sailors because the game is 
wantonly—some might say gleefully—unfair. You

start out with four measly health points that 
a crowd of zombies can chew through in seconds;

you&#39;re obliged to escort survivors along 
circuitous routes back to base who all

have the self-preservation instincts and 
pathfinding ability of a moth in a disco.

And then there are the unique psychopath 
boss fights against quirky people who all

went off the deep end when the apocalypse 
started, are all weirdly physically large,

and can all stunlock you like you&#39;re a swingball 
set. But you know something? I find Dead Rising

quite easy. Why? Because I&#39;ve played it a lot. 
And having done so, I know to hightail it to the

coffee shop as soon as you leave the security room 
to grab three orange juices and the secret katana

from the top of the awning. It&#39;s a game almost 
unique in the way it&#39;s built around learning and

experimenting. You can restart the game at any 
point with your levels and upgrades still intact

just to drive that point home like a gumball 
machine into a decomposing solar plexus. But

I had an even easier time playing Druh Druh 
because of all the little gameplay tweaks

filing its more blatantly unfair points down. 
Okay, for the people like me who enjoyed the

original and who need to get out of here quickly 
to replace their catheter bags, let&#39;s go over what

&quot;remaster&quot; means in this case. Well, there&#39;s 
a lot of focus on the visuals. It&#39;s replaced

all the characters with high-def models that make 
Frank look somehow even more disquieting with all

the extra pores and wrinkles giving everyone 
a vibe of suffering from severe dehydration.

They&#39;ve also added autosaving, 
marginally less moronic NPC pathfinding,

and made Frank&#39;s special moves easier to crack 
off; the dodge roll in particular making it a

lot easier to escape stunlock—hell, now 
it&#39;s one button press. Dodge rolling,

high difficulty? Is Dead Rising a Soulslike 
now? If coffee creamer counts as Estus, maybe,

and if Frank could be persuaded not to chug 
the whole gallon in one, the fat bastard. I&#39;m

pretty sure the damage on the mini-chainsaw 
has been nerfed. That was always my go-to;

it used to fuck up psychopaths like 
a Dead by Daylight balance patch;

it&#39;s a tad bit chippier now. And there are a few 
notable changes reflecting a desire to switch the

drive shaft to manual from problematic, if you 
catch my drift. You no longer get bonus erotica

points for taking pictures up the skirts and down 
the cleavages of frightened female survivors,

thus depriving the one female main character 
who hangs out in the safe room with her tits

hanging out of the one thing that made her not 
completely bloody useless. And there&#39;s a mandatory

psychopath fight near the end against a weirdly 
physically large Chinese man that&#39;s been changed

to yet another weirdly physically large white 
American dude. Coh, comes to something when even

the &quot;over-the-top gonzo disembowel zombies in your 
underpants&quot; games can&#39;t be a bit cheeky as well.

In all seriousness, yay for acknowledging past 
dodginess, I suppose, but the way you do that is

you put a hand-wringing disclaimer at the start, 
putting Speedy Gonzales in the proper context of

its time; you don&#39;t remake the whole thing with 
Speedy Gonzales wearing a bowler hat and talking

in a Glaswegian accent. Get out of here with this 
Star Wars Remastered Edition revisionist history

bullshit. So, all that aside, how does Dead Rising 
1 hold up? Well, there&#39;s still a lot I like. I get

the sense the mall was mapped out before the 
designers figured out how the game would work,

and that&#39;s probably why every time you escort a 
survivor home, you have to take them through one

specific door, a warehouse, around an S-bend 
of shelves, up an elevator, across a rooftop,

&#39;round the garden path, and up a passing 
rhinoceros&#39; bum crack. It lends an adorably janky,

experimental feel, like student filmmakers trying 
to pass off various angles of the corner of their

dad&#39;s unfinished basement as the depths of an 
alien-infested moon colony. Even with the steps

to make the game easier and the removal of racist 
bits so you don&#39;t keep dropping your controller to

clutch your pearls, I imagine it&#39;ll still be 
punishing for completely new players used to

modern games leading them around by the nose 
with big, obvious objective markers pointing

directly away from hungry zombies&#39; mouths, 
and frankly, that thought makes me titter.

But while I still like the Dead Rising formula, 
I think that formula was perfected in Dead Rising

2 with the addition of combo weapons. Without 
that, the process of learning to maximize one&#39;s

offensive potential consists of figuring out where 
the mini-chainsaw respawns and then spending the

whole game making weird braying sounds with your 
lips. And the air kinda goes out of Dead Rising

1 near the end of the main story when the special 
forces arrive. Who&#39;d have thought a game largely

focused on sailing across oceans of zombies on 
the Good Ship Lawnmower would lose something

after all the zombies bugger off to be replaced by 
a load of spongy, gun-toting fun police? Fact is,

the existing Steam version was fine, with visuals 
that didn&#39;t bounce around the uncanny valley like

a ping pong ball made of grotesque, wrinkly 
flesh, so from a philosophical perspective,

I question the point of this whole revisionist 
remastering process, especially with a subject

whose original appeal lay largely in innovations 
that have since been improved upon. &quot;Boy,

what an interesting game,&quot; one might say. 
&quot;I wonder how future games will build upon

these ideas.&quot; &quot;Well, I imagine they&#39;ll milk 
it for sequels for a while until one cuts

out all the unique idiosyncrasies for the 
sake of broader appeal and turns the main

character into an insufferable cockwomble.&quot; 
&quot;Oh, you&#39;re such a buzzkill, causality.&quot;
